rules said that they didn't allow siblings to be in the

there are only enough students for one fifth grade and for one sixth grade
but there were sufficient students to have to fourth grade
. So we just put you back into fourth grade so
that you could each have the experience of having being in your own classroom
and having that separation. Well that
. Cracked the surface. The hard
crust of my belief that I was
learnable unteachable. That I was different from
everyone else and could never learn the way they did. That was huge
. As that course as my participation in those courses
continued. I.
He was able to say I did enough
work to really get it
in my in my bones in my in my core
that that was a story that I made up
. After one of my class courses I remember
clearly going back to work. And sitting to the right.
My computer. Was a. Foot high
stack at least. Of. Client
files that had an injury that required data entry that I hadn't done
yet because I was so intimidated by the computers that I
just I was terrified. And I can clearly remember walking into my office sitting
down and going OK well you know what. Now I get to instead of
I have to deal with this data entry. And
it really transformed from I'm too stupid to
learn how to do this too. I get to create
opportunities for other people to be of assistance to me when I need it. Now that doesn't mean
that I still don't have breakdowns when I get you know a regular basis but
. That really was transformative to me
. Another. Another huge gift
through landmark was a course
in which we unconcealed our
point of view a point of view you know we all think we're great communicators
right. That we know how to do it in a more effective at it depends on the day. Yeah
right in the moment and in reality what we are typically doing is
using the communication skills that we inherited from our
families that communicate so that you can mold it so that you can manipulate
maneuver you know hide
defend or protect whatever but. In
this course. It's called communication access to power course
we had the opportunity to conceal our individual point of
view and that point of view is made up of
the formula. I'm not X. Y.
it with me. OK well. It's fairly it
was always fairly easy for me to come up with. M Y. You know I'm
I'm an adequate I'm stupid I'm ugly I'm
not wanted or you know whatever. But to come up with that I'm not.
Part of the equation first is really takes some personal
Examination. Well I finally came up with it. I'm not
wanted. I'm invisible
. And when I got it that's
how I have looked and experienced life ever since
. Childhood. And was able to
set it aside. It's like it's like discovering
the the Wizard of Oz behind the curtain
. When I you know I that will always be in my
worldview always be my point of view. But I now know I have the tools to
be able to move it aside and get that know what is in my head
about how I am not wanted and I'm invisible. Out of the way.
So that that has made a profound shift possible for me
and that's after I was hit by a car by
somebody who was simply not paying attention. In
this that I was doing everything right. And she just backed up out of her
driveway into the public space the sidewalk and threw me into the street
. And honey I am not invisible
but that's what I've lived with lived under all my life until now.
Until I discovered.
What other questions do you have.
You tell me a little bit more about your career.
From the left off I think when you were at the school for the opening line OK And then
I moved into rehab teaching where I served for county rural area and
that was very interesting. I just I happened to be fortunate enough that
the first person I went to see whose home I went into
the African-American.
Like mouthpiece for the community. OK. And once she really
got that I had nothing to do with her food stamps or her
housing money for food for housing that I was really there to
be of service to her
. I got access to the homes of many many people that that
I know have never had you know young white woman coming in
and I learned so much by those by those folks
and it was great and I returned to Oregon and I was hired
as a rehabilitation counselor and
I did that.
But I much prefer to be involved with people
in their space now
. Interesting. Yeah I mean I certainly see the point of rehabilitation
counseling. I mean it's you know having a job that you that you love and
can.
Experience success and make a difference in the world and all those things that's really great.
But and I'm I'm much more drawn to
how you live your life if you don't know how to how to fix your if you if you're a
coffee lover and you don't know how to fix it and you don't know how to do your laundry you're going to
have to
die. I'm far more able to interact with people
in a way that gives them space to be who they are no
matter what kind of job you get. Probably won't keep it very long so I have I have. I
moved into rehabilitation teaching which I just loved.
I did serve. I was assistant director of rehabilitation services for the
commission for the blind for two years or so and
in that program I supervised the independent living program
for folks fifty five and better and I really loved that
. I mean that was the population that I was very interested in working with
and. But again I love doing the
hands on living with vision loss kinds of things. And so
I. Facilitated one of those when I was in that position of
assistant director of rehabilitation services and I went oh I missed this I want to be on the field
. So I demoted myself back into the field. Which is what I did for
years and I go into people's homes and and. Be a resource for
them to be able to. I regained or build
confidence and skills sufficient so they could live the
lives of their choice and.
So I did that for approximately thirty years. I've also and I did
. Put myself
into the. Introduction
leadership program with Landmark Education and became a second
introduction leader who is blind in the world. And did that
for two years and. Then
. Also
. My mother was a very well she still is
she's now ninety seven.
Living here in New York independently and when I was a little girl and
every once in a while she'd say get the hairbrush. That you
think that would mean run right but what I meant was if you brush my hair or
scratch my back or massage my feet I'll read out loud to you.
Well I am a glutton to you know I unnerved to be read out loud to
you and so when I was in graduate school the church that I was attending
the pastor has a degenerative
disease that is one of his doctors thought regular massage would
be of use. So he asked if anybody in the congregation was a licensed
listeners and I said no I'm not but I've done it all my life and I'll go
get licensed so I did I was the first blind person licensed as a
massage technician in Oregon and that.
If I can remember taking the exam I
needed I needed to have something to read it to me. And so they said well we'll have
somebody read it. And I said Oh no thank you I will provide my own
reader. I do require that they are able to pronounce the words correctly
. I was interested in having somebody who's who English was their
second or third language try to read the terminology that's
required to be able to deal with it. When you're taking the
exam so they made my SO I did I had a friend who
taught medical technology medical transcription and
I knew she could pronounce the words correctly. They made her sign a
promissory statement that she would not cheat for me. I was so offended
she was too. We almost got up and left. You know
one of the challenges for me in school was all my tests had to be read out
loud to me and they'd be read typically in the back of the room by the teacher
of whom I was very. Intimidated and if
I even suspected that I didn't know the answer I would
. Pass the question and they would beg me to read to
let me read it to you again and I just say no. If I couldn't do it the first
time right I would. I was not a risk taker in any way.
When I was I worked for the commission for the Blind in
Oregon for a number of years and then quit because I was married to my second husband
and he was getting transferred to another state.
When I came back to Oregon and I was job hunting
I contacted a good friend of mine who was I had a number of.
Friends and colleagues who were still working for the commission for the blind and I
called one of them and she was then the acting director of rehabilitation
for the state. And. Although I had application
several other places she offered me a job to come back to the Commission for the
blind and she said she'd do it under one condition and that was that I become
fluent in Braille.
Well well well. There's a woman who knows me well
and I said OK And so I did it. Now I will never be
a casual reader.
And I will never be a casual print reader. But I can do it and
I won't have Braille. It's one of the areas of my life that
I I profoundly regret not
having access to as a child to learn because I got
to not because I have to. And
that that's one of my lifelong regrets because
Braille is such a gift. It's so
much fun and infecting a co-worker
at the commission for the blind. Wrote a textbook. Specifically for
people who were transferring from print to braille people that have been longtime print readers
into Braille. It's a book called Reading with
feeling. Is that a cool title here and you know so she
she. Created a curriculum that got you reading text by the end
of the first lesson. NOT A through E. which is typically how Braille
is taught to adults which is very condescending. So
an Strauss book series reading with feeling is what
I highly recommend her to get a hold of it's out there is there was a published
I don't know I have the information you know you could find it and all of the proceeds
. She didn't keep any of the money I don't even know where when I get a commission for that one
Yeah I'd be interested to create a book.
What else I. OK so I got licensed as misuse. I've never had to
do it to pay the rent. I've always been able to give it away. And
the last chapter of my life I
say probably for the last. Three years before I was hit by the car
. And no more than that. Anyway I was a hospice volunteer
I have because of my license as an assistant with a delivery of about twelve
babies and then they're functioning primarily as a
doula a support to the mother whatever you want I'll do if you want me to smoke a
cigar but the day I will.
Thank God no one ever wanted me to and then I
moved into donating massage to hospice
patients. Yeah I know but I haven't had the core strength
sufficient core strength or energy to be able to do full body massages
since I was hit by the car and have also experienced breast
cancer and got to got to do that dance.
And have served currently serving on the board of directors
for an organization called oral hall foundation O R A L.
New word H U L L foundation that's the name of
the woman who donated her twenty two acre parcel of land in
just east of Portland Oregon to be used as a retreat
center for folks who are blind. And
since I have retired from the commission for the blind I did
that in one thousand in two thousand and ten. We've created not only do we
have a variety of recreational.
Experience is available we have different we we do camps
for. For children through the local school district
for families and for adults. We have moderate
adventure and high adventure camps that people come from all over the
country to experience you know if you want to skydive or
bungee jump or can you now kayak or horseback riding.
We have all kinds of stuff but I also We've recently
started living with vision loss seminars that I
facilitate the. Three day events for folk to come out and
. Get to. Address those concerns that
. Are common for folks that are
dealing with Asian allies. So I'm on that board and I served on the
board for my church and. I've also been a very active
in Lions club's international search is the president
of the oldest club in Oregon in
Portland downtown club which is. No. What ninety four years old
. And had the opportunity to
serve as a. District Governor.
So essentially I was the C.E.O. of forty seven Lions Clubs and
that Lions is the largest service club in the world
and we are the number one non-governmental organization in the
category of finances. So one hundred percent of the money that we raise from the
public is used for public service. And that includes
vision restoration. Vision preservation and disaster
relief. And in the capacity of working with lions as a lion
I have gone to Mexico three different years. I'm for a ten
day vision clinics and you know we all pay our own way
. So when I was working I told the woman
who facilitates that that trip I said you know I'm happy to go happy to pay my own way
but I really want to be able to provide a service that will make a difference. Is
it OK if I take down white canes. And she said sure. So
they put the word out for folks who are blind. To come. If they were interested
in getting a white cane and so that's what I've done for three years and
I. Look forward to doing it again. Next year. And now
. One of the. One of the most
memorable clients was a approximately seven year old maintained
then holding on to the pants leg of her father she never walked
alone in her life. Even in her own home because the
terminology the term for disability in Central and South America
is Minos Valley doles which means minus value.
Well honey if that's who you think you are then by God you're going to live up to it
. And so with the
support of a fabulous young mother who was my translator
I was able to put a cane in her hand and while I'm describing to her
and her parents what to do she grabs the cane takes off running
around the room exploring by herself and laughing the rest of us were
crying it was really great. So. I love doing
the be a part of that kind of stuff. OK So
Lyons has been important to me in my church my family do a lot of
traveling.
With. And just really passionate about it.
Creating a space for people to figure out new ways to
do things that they have to do need to want to and would
like to. If it's legal I'll help them figure it out.
OK. He's helping us to question
things he'd like to share. I'm just looking at my watch and
did you have to leave three now. OK
. Well I think.
A. Couple areas that come to mind that that and that
from personal experience I know that dealing with
sexual abuse is unfortunately very common
with women with disabilities. Girls and women.
And I know that that has a profound effect certainly has on me
and it has many other people. So the
more people can be open about it and address
it. And break the cycle the
better. And also aging is
a huge challenge. I'm now sixty seven and.
I am determined. To
age with the greatest amount of.
Grace and dignity and humor and just as the parts wear
out and we can't do things the way we used to that's
that's just life you know. So keeping
keeping in as good a physical shape as possible.
I know that obesity is a as having a profound effect on
our society. I'm.
Very lucky to have great genes and
now I'm you know dealing with the profound effect of diabetes
is you know it's the it's the largest cause of
vision loss in young adults but it rarely gets talked about.
So. You know it's really important that just
because you don't know what's outside your living room. Get out there anyway
and explore you know a cane using a white cane
or a dog or a walker or whatever you need. It's not
it's to your advantage. I don't use a white cane for many many years
because I was I was afraid that I would be singled out and be more
vulnerable. However what I learned is that
. Using a white cane appropriately makes me much less
vulnerable because I cannot walk. You know most people and
I you know my hand is up and I'm connected to what's
around me. People don't know how much or how little I can see. And even
though I visually see you know physically see very
little I am. You know
I go out of my way to be alert and.
Pay attention to what's going on around me and I encourage all
of our readers to do the same and if I can be
a resource to anybody in any way it's my pleasure to do so
. I have people stop me on the street. In five years I'm walking with my
cane. You know we're writing on an airplane or on a bus and saying
you know my mother has macular degeneration what I'm going to do with her. So I'll always be a
teacher you know and most of the time I love doing it.
So yeah thank you for the opportunity to to come in
. I'm sure there's more I know there's lots of other chapters I haven't mentioned but
if any of what I have shared today can be a
resource or support or encourage women to other people. I'm proud to do
it.
Thank you so much.
